abstract.text: The Mapbox Maps SDK v11 introduces improvements to how Mapbox works on iOS platforms, as well as changes to how developers use the SDK. This document summarizes the most important changes - such as new features, deprecated APIs, and breaking changes - and walks you through how to upgrade an application using v10 of the Mapbox Maps SDK to v11.

inlineContent.text: Update your app‚Äôs dependencies to use versions 11+ of the Mapbox Maps SDK for iOS. We distribute the SDK through Swift Package Manager (SPM), CocoaPods, and Direct Download. Full instructions are found

We‚Äôre excited to announce the launch of Mapbox Standard, our latest Mapbox style, now accessible to all customers in a beta version. The new Mapbox Standard core style enables a highly performant and elegant 3D mapping experience with powerful dynamic lighting capabilities, landmark 3D buildings, and an expertly crafted symbolic aesthetic. With Mapbox Standard, we are also introducing a new paradigm for how to interact with map styles based around style importing (see below section for more details).
To set Mapbox Standard as the style for your map in v11 you can use the same
convenience variables from v10 like below. Mapbox Standard is the new default style, so not setting a
means your map will use Mapbox Standard.
The Mapbox Standard style features 4 light presets:
. The style light preset can be changed from the default,
, to another preset with a single line of code. Here you identify which imported style (
config on, as well as the value (
) you want to change it to.
Changing the light preset will alter the colors and shadows on your map to reflect the time of day. For more information, check out the New 3D Lighting API section.
Similarly, you can set other configuration properties on the Standard style such as showing POIs, place labels, or specific fonts:
The Standard style offers 6 configuration properties for developers to change when they import it into their own style:
Shows and hides place label layers.
Shows and hides all road labels, including road shields.
Shows or hides all POI icons and text.
Shows or hides all transit icons and text.
Defines font family for the style from predefined options.
Mapbox Standard is making adding your own data layers easier for you through the concept of
s are pre-specified locations in the style where your layer will be added to (such as on top of existing land layers, but below all labels). To do this, we‚Äôve added a new
. This property allows you to identify which

in the Mapbox Standard your new layer should be placed in. To add custom layers in the appropriate location in the Standard style layer stack, we added 3 carefully designed slots that you can leverage to place your layer. These slots will remain stable, so you can be sure that your own map won‚Äôt break even as the basemap evolves automatically.
Above lines (roads, etc.) and behind 3D buildings
Above POI labels and behind Place and Transit labels
Above all existing layers in the style
For the new Standard style, you can only add layers to these three slots (
Similar to the classic Mapbox styles, you can still use the layer position in

method when importing the Standard Style. However, this method is only applicable to custom layers you have added yourself. If you add two layers to the same slot with a specified layer position the latter will define the order of the layers in that slot.
Standard is aware of the map lighting configuration using the

expression, which returns you an aggregated value of your light settings. This returns a value which ranges from 0 (darkest) to 1 (brightest). In darker lights, you make the individual layers light up by using the new

expressions, which allow you to add emissive light to different layer types and for example keep texts legible in all light settings. If your custom layers seem too dark, try adjusting the emissive strength of these layers.

The underlying design paradigm to the Standard style is different from what you know from the classic core styles. Mapbox manages the basemap experience and surfaces key global styling configurations - in return, you get a cohesive visual experience and an evergreen map, always featuring the latest data, styling and rendering features compatible with your SDK. The configuration options make interactions with the basemap simpler than before. During the beta phase, we are piloting these configurations - we welcome feedback on the beta configurations. If you have feedback or questions about the Standard beta style reach out to:

You can customize the overall color of your Standard experience easily by adjusting the 3D light settings. Individual basemap layers and/or color values can‚Äôt be adjusted, but all the flexibility offered by the style specification can be applied to custom layers while keeping interaction with the basemap simple through

To work with styles like Mapbox Standard, we‚Äôve introduced new Style APIs that allow you to import other styles into the main style you display to your users. These styles will be imported by reference, so updates to them will be reflected in your main style without additional work needed on your side. For example, imagine you have style A and style B. The Style API will allow you to import A into B. Upon importing, you can set configurations that apply to A and adjust them at runtime. The configuration properties for the imported style A will depend on what the creator of style A chooses to be configurable. For the Standard style, 6 configuration properties are available for setting lighting, fonts, and label display options (see The Mapbox Standard Style section above).
To import a style, you should add an ‚Äúimports‚Äù section to your
. In the above example, you would add this ‚Äúimports‚Äù section to your Style JSON for B to import style A and set various configurations such as
For a full example of importing a style, please check out our

, which returns all of the configuration properties of the style import with the passed Id
, which returns the specified configuration property of the style import with the passed Id
, which sets all of the configuration properties of the style import with the passed Id
, which sets the specified configuration property of the style import with the passed Id
In addition to modifying the configuration properties of the imported styles, you can add your own layers to the imported style through the concept of
s are pre-specified locations in the imported style where your layer will be added to (such as on top of existing land layers, but below all labels). To do this, we‚Äôve added a new
. This property allows you to identify which
in the imported style your new layer should be placed in.
We‚Äôre excited to announce the launch of SwiftUI support in Mapbox Maps SDK. SwiftUI makes it even easier to integrate Mapbox Maps in your application.
For more details, please read the
have been reworked. The new event system is serialization-free, which brings more type safety and eliminates possible deserialization errors that could take place in v10 MapboxMaps SDK.
As a bonus, this new type system supports the

code: guard let self = self else { return }
// Observe only the next style loading event

inlineContent.text: The new event endpoints such as
s that allow you to observe any events over time. While you are interested in receiving updates corresponding to these events you simply store the cancelation tokens returned from
methods. When the token is deallocated, the subscription will be automatically canceled and you will stop receiving updates.
, so Combine usage in iOS 13+ targets is recommended:
We introduce support for Dynamic View Annotations that automatically position themselves at any geometry (
). For example, you can visualize ETA labels attached to the route line that is rendered by
To make View Annotations simpler to use, we introduce new
object, that helps create an annotation from any UIView:

code: let annotation = ViewAnnotation(coordinate: coordinate, view: view)

inlineContent.text: The following example uses a dynamic

code: annotation.variableAnchors = .all // Allow anchor to be displayed in all directions.
// When annotation content is changed, call `setNeedsUpdateSize()` for proper positioning.

inlineContent.text: The new Dynamic View Annotations are supported in SwiftUI, check out the

The new API allows you to assign Tap and Long Press gestures handlers to Annotations, Layers, and the Map. The handlers are called according to the rendered layer position starting from the top-most. The map handler is called when neither annotation nor layer handle the gesture.

code: return true // the polygon handled the tap, do not propagate
return true // layer handled the tap, do not propagate
// this handler is called when neither annotation nor layer handled the tap.

inlineContent.text: For more details, please read the

content.text: 2.6 Access Token and Map Options management

inlineContent.text: The access token for every Mapbox SDK can now be set via single call of
. By default, Mapbox SDKs will try to initialize it upon framework initialization time from:
property list value in the app bundle;
If you wish to set access token programmatically, it is highly recommended to set it before initializing a
Configurations for the external resources used by Maps API can now be set via
To clear the temporary map data, use the
The TileStore also no longer accepts access token as part of its options.
In v11 we‚Äôve introduced new experimental lighting APIs to give you control of lighting and shadows in your map when using 3D objects:
. We‚Äôve also added new APIs on

s to support this 3D lighting styling and enhance your ability to work with 3D model layers. Together, these properties can illuminate your 3D objects such as buildings and terrain to provide a more realistic and immersive map experience for your users. These properties can be set at runtime to follow the time of day, a particular mood, or other lighting goals in your map. Check out our example
We introduced several changes to the location-related classes and protocols that will make working with location easier.
are now only responsible for providing location updates. The
doesn‚Äôt manage the permissions, accuracy authorization, or heading anymore.
are now responsible for providing the heading (compass) updates. The
is optional and only needed if you use
have been separated because their updates can come from the different sources. This also allows us to animate the heading quicker than the location which results in more responsive puck behavior.
In case you need to drive the puck with custom location data, the
protocol is easy to implement in

code: // Override the location provider with the custom one.

inlineContent.text: In case you also need to supply a custom heading (compass) data, implement the
was simplified too. Now it only manages the the location puck, not the
only determine the puck appearance. If you need to fine-tune the location provider itself, do it directly via the default
or your own custom provider implementation.
. You can use them to observe puck in the same way, as Map Events (see section 2.2).

code: // Adjust puck-connected elements (route line, annotations) here.

inlineContent.text: As a bonus, you now can use a Combine
to drive the puck location updates:
Please check out a more detailed example
In v11, we have refined the Camera API introduced in v10 to improve developer ergonomics. These changes include several minor updates to usability:
The SDK now exposes the owner property on
, allowing you to more easily identify the owner.

The cameraFor methods (cameraForCoordinatesArray, cameraForLocationArray, and cameraForCoordinateBounds) have been simplified and aligned with our Android and Web SDKs. Passing a padding parameter is now optional, and additional optional maxZoom and offset parameters are available for cameraForCoordinateBounds.
Finally, cameraState can now be accessed through mapboxMap rather than directly on mapView.
The Maps SDK introduces signpost recording support. Signposts are important instruments for analyzing performance and detecting bottlenecks in your code.
Please note that these options will enable all available Maps SDK components for tracing.
Signposts in the Maps SDK are currently separated into two components:
Rendering engine (responsible for almost every rendering aspect in the
Maps SDK functionality like gestures, animations, view annotations, and so on.
SDK generates a lot of event for each frame, so Instruments might skip some of them in
mode to preserve full signpost data (
To limit signposts generation for a single component, please use the following API:
To configure tracing components through environment variable use comma separator like:
to disable tracing through environment variable.
API takes precedence over environment variable value. All values are case-insensitive.
provides an experimental API to record and replay map interaction sessions. Such recordings can be used to debug issues which require multiple steps to reproduce. Usage example can be found
that returns tile Ids covering the map. Use
to identify which tile range to return tile Ids for.

code: let tileCoverOptions = TileCoverOptions(tileSize: 512, minZoom: 4, maxZoom: 8, roundZoom: true)

parameter in the initializer. It will make style manipulation code less error-prone.
Contrary to that, some layers (such as
properties. To clean up the code we removed them from those layers and from the
Instead of setting the whole new GeoJSON object anew every time a single feature has changed, now you can apply more granular, partial GeoJSON updates.
If your features have associated identifiers - you can add, update and remove them on individual basis in your
s hosting a large amount of features - in this case adding a feature can be up to 4x faster with partial update API.
are not in use anymore and got removed, instead use
While maintaing the existing gesture approach we made minor improvements. In v11 we now:
allow animation during any ongoing gestures
enable zoom during a drag gesture
to be able to detect rotation separately from other gestures.
To further improve the performance of 3D model layer, we have replaced Puck 3D‚Äôs default
, which will keep the 3D model size constant across different zoom levels.
While this means that Puck 3D‚Äôs size should render similarly to v10, it does introduces a behavior breaking change - that
needs to be adjusted to correctly render the puck (in testing we found the adjustment to be around 100x of v10
value, but that could vary depending on other properties etc.).

content.text: 3. Replace Deprecated APIs and Address Breaking Changes

inlineContent.text: Check for any deprecated APIs in your code and replace them with the recommended alternatives. Deprecated APIs may be removed in future releases.
We‚Äôve simplified MapboxMap and Snapshot so you can now access Style APIs directly from
instance rather than going through the deprecated Style object. For example:

content.text: 3.7 Maps SDK no longer reexport MetalKit and UIKit

inlineContent.text: Mapbox Maps SDK no longer reexports MetalKit and UIKit frameworks, so you will need to import them as needed for your code. In v10 version you could omit
statement, but that is no longer possible.
have been removed from public visibility.
It is thus no longer possible to override the HTTP stack.
If you need to set a HTTP interceptor you can do it via the
function no longer exists and the signature of
have been changed to return a value through a continuation.
constants to set additional HttpRequest parameters.

code: let httpRequest = HttpRequest(method: HttpMethod.get, url: "", headers: [:], keepCompression: false, timeout: 0,
networkRestriction: NetworkRestriction.none, sdkInformation: sdkInformation, body: nil)
let httpRequest = HttpRequest(method: HttpMethod.get, url: "", headers: [:], timeout: 0, networkRestriction: NetworkRestriction.none,
sdkInformation: sdkInformation, body: nil, flags: HttpRequestFlags.none)

content.text: 3.11 Bearing updates are disabled by default.

inlineContent.text: MapView wouldn‚Äôt redraw on each device compass update and should significantly reduce CPU usage for applications that
only display user location without bearing/heading indication.
If your application still need to rotate puck image according to device heading or location course, enable the option as:

content.text: 4. Update APIs deprecated in v10 which have been removed in v11

inlineContent.text: and removed in v11. Along with this, constructor
has also been removed, instead please use
have been removed, however, we have provided a shim to smoothen the migration process from v10 to v11. Please refer to the Type-safe Events API section to update your events code.
The following transition properties have been removed from our layers:
property now only supports a constant value, instead of
now requires class semantic for implementation.
Map size is now synced to the size of the Metal view
option was removed, whenever terrain is present layer order is now automatically adjusted for better performance. Previously, optimization was the default.
Test your app thoroughly after making the changes to ensure everything is working as expected.
Following the above steps will help you migrate your app to the latest version of the Mapbox Maps SDK for Android. If you encounter any issues during the migration process, refer to the
or reach out to the Mapbox support team for assistance.

abstract.text: The camera has changed. This event is emitted whenever the visible viewport
changes due to the MapView‚Äôs size changing or when the camera
is modified by calling camera methods. The event is emitted synchronously,
so that an updated camera state can be fetched immediately.
A spherical dome around the map that is always rendered behind all other layers.

is the preferred method for atmospheric styling. Sky layer is not supported by the globe projection, and will be phased out in future major release.

An
defines a formula for computing the value of any layout property, paint property,
or filter within a map style. Expressions allow you to style data with multiple feature
properties at once, apply conditional logic, and manipulate data with mathematical, logical, and
string operators. This allows for sophisticated runtime styling.
